0:11 graphic is wrong. the current is not changing.

Electric charges and magnetic poles are made of and surrounded by microscopic particles known as Electric and magnetic flux. Density of these particles is maximum at the centre of charge and magnetic pole which decreases outward. These particles produce electric and magnetic fields. Electric and magnetic particles are entangled and move in tandem at right angle to each other. Electric flux and electric field are different entities. Electric flux is a physical object while electric field is force with magnitude and direction. There is no electric or magnetic field around single charge or magnetic pole. Electric and magnetic fields appear when fluxes of 2 or more charges or magnetic poles interact. Interaction b/w like charges/poles increases flux density which produces repulsive force field while Interaction b/w opposite charges decreases flux density which produces attractive force field. Assuming electric and magnetic flux is made of microscopic particles, maxwell equations can be modified as; 1st. Equation. • Electric charge q is made of and is surrounded by  microscopic particles called electric flux. • Density of microscopic particles/ electric flux at any closed surface is proportional to total charge contained inside the closed surface. • Interaction b/w fluxes of electric charges produces electric field. 2nd Equation; • Magnetic pole is  made of and is surrounded by microscopic particles/ magnetic flux. • Magnetic poles  come as 2 conjoined  opposite poles with  permanent attractive force field  b/w the poles. • Due to Interaction b/w opposite fluxes,  flux density in the middle of the poles is zero. 3rd. Equation  • A moving and changing magnetic flux induces moving and changing electric flux which induces changing electric current in a conductor. •  A moving and constant magnetic flux produces  static electric field which can't induce current in conductor. 4th Equation; •  A moving and changing electric flux produces a moving and changing magnetic flux. •A moving and constant electric flux produces static magnetic flux.

An honest review that I hope @crashcourse will consider in future.  1. Speed: I know I have a pause button and can watch it at a slower speed. It had always been the routine. But this time they've taken it a bit too far. It's okay to stretch a video from 10 mins to 15 mins. The viewers won't treat it as a long video. If you still insist to keep it short, try reducing the content rather than cramming everything into 10 mins. 2. Content: A lot of secondary details overshadowed the actual content of the course. The intention of watching a CrashCourse video is to understand a topic in the simplest way possible, and not just brushing up what we've already learnt. The content seemed like a summary of the chapter aimed at someone who's already studied the topic. If I were new to Maxwell's Equation, I'd as lost as I'm in the classroom. So the whole point of this video becomes moot. 3. Delivery: Dr. Shini is a brilliant physicist, and could've done a lot to make us appreciate the topic. Rather she just gives a flat delivery of the script like the evening bullet news. It's not just the speed, but it seemed more like reading notes straight from the book. I'd love it if She could weigh the important concepts more heavily and let the secondary equations run in the background as additional reference. 4. Creativity: Fancy colours and cool animations to the content didn't just cut it. Please try to make us visualize what you're presenting. I was eagerly waiting for an "Ah! ha!" moment when she was explaining the equations. The math and all was cool, but if it was just those equations and their derivations, we could've gone back to books. Expecting more efforts in making us realize the beauty of Maxwell's Laws rather than the nitty-gritty.  However, big thanks for creating such awesome contents and sharing for free... much appreciated. Keep up this great work!

God i hate general physics 2. General physics 1 with kinematics is so much more enticing and infinitely simpler, the whole class can be taught using nothing but Algebraic equations where as general physics 2 pretty much requires an extensive knowledge of calculus and complex algebra. A single clsss covers coulomb’s law, ampere’s law, gauss’s law, Maxwell’s equations, Einstein’s Relativity, lenz’s law, Kirchhoff's laws of closed loops, ohm’s law, Biot–Savart law it just keeps going with all of them being incredibly simple but vastly over complicated by moronic professors. The disconnect in my opinion is when these equations bring back skeletons from calculus because when you arrive at this class you most likely have already went through calc1,2,3 and most likely in DE, you can about imagine how much you can forget and most physicists don’t bother reiterating fundamental concepts of calculus in reference to physics, mathematicians don’t like to explain how things relate to physics and focus purely on the mathematics. Polar opposite of each other when they should be complementary of each other. The classes actively fight against each other and god forbid you are also in a general Electrical Circuits class. I like to call it Confusion City when all of these beasts fight each other conceptually. Its like Different accents of the same language, imagine a cockney British guy, a Southern Alabama guy, and a Icelandic guy all trying to explain how to make a hot pocket at the same time... its all the same steps but they all have their own spin on the way they explain it.

As an educator, I'd like to point out that people tend to only be able to hold a very small number of things in their heads at once-- somewhere between five to seven. That's simple things, like one digit numbers. The only reason any of us can do more complex tasks than that is because of "chunking" where we eventually form large single units out of things we've already learned have significance-- like being able to remember a long string of numbers because it's a combination of your sister's birthday, your weight, your friend's address, and your social security number, backwards. This video is horrible because it introduces a bazillion new names for things and calculus concepts as if it's a Micro-Machines commercial from the '80s with that guy who talks a million miles a minute. There's no way to chunk any of this, unless someone already knows it.

For those struggling with the speed of info (as I did), I recommend pausing the video to catch your breath, take a few notes. You can also change the speed of the playback by clicking on the gear icon and selecting one of 3 slower speeds (0.25X, 0.5X, or 0.75X). These simple customizations are what make learning from recorded videos so great!  I didn't expect a 10 minute video (or 15 minute video, if playing at a slower speed!) to substitute for a semester long college physics or engineering course, but it was a decent overview for those of us who have had some training in this area, but are rusty.

Vector Calculus & Maxwell's Equations In Vector Calculus in Engineering Mathematics, Learned how to derive 1) Gradient of function f(x,y,z) 2) Divergence of Vector function  3) Curl of Vector function  Thanks to IEI, I could understand derivation of Maxwell's Equations properly. Since 2003 in BSC Physics Honours it has been a difficult problem. Maxwell's Equation has helped us understand Electric Fields, Magnetic Fields by establishing relation between electric & magnetic field, understand light waves, Discover knowledge of VIBGYOR, Discover wavelength & frequency of light waves of different colours. The knowledge of all elements in periodic table could only be discovered after Maxwell calculated these equations with Vector Calculus & many scientific experiments applied these equations. Concepts of AM, FM in Radio waves also could be engineered & designed with Vector Fields equations.

I don't know if somebody has mentioned it or not, but while these are Maxwell's equations, they are the Heaviside formulation of Maxwell's equations. Maxwell's original equations where 20 equations in 20 variables. Heaviside reformulated them into four vector differential equations that you are showing here but not giving him due credit.  " thereby reducing twelve of the original twenty equations in twenty unknowns down to the four differential equations in two unknowns we now know as Maxwell's equations." -Wiki

Really nice course, but you forgot to mention the admirable effort of Oliver Heaviside, he was the one behind the so elegant Maxwell's Field Equation, we, nowadays use and manly the one that brought those concepts from mathematics and physics to engineering.

Watching this video I have realised that this series is actually extremely brilliant... for engineers. Seriously when you write Maxwell's equations first of all you write them in integral form. No respectable physicist would since the differential form gives a more explicit explanation of the mechanics of EM and furthermore are much easier to work with when you are dealing with electromagnetic waves and optics and such. Furthermore flux is an idiotic measurement. It is non-existent. You cannot measure the flux but simply the force that the fields impart of some object. However the same could be said about potentials and vector potentials, something that you have done nothing to explain in this series. If you want to teach people about EM make sure that they understand the mathematics first (vector-analysis or vector-calculus, same thing).

For those interested in a more fundamental version of maxwell laws: Rot(E)=-∂B/∂t                      (Maxwell-Faraday) div(E)=ρ/ε0                         (Maxwell-Gauss) div(B)=0                               (Maxwell-Thomson) Rot(B)=μ0*j+μ0*ε0*∂E/∂t (Maxwell-Ampère) Gauss and Ampere theoremes can be proved by those set of equations using some relations like the Ostrogradski formula or the Stokes formula - Rot and div are vectorial operators - j is a vector called volumic density of current (translated from french name densité volumique de courant) - ε0 and μ0 are the famous constants - ∂B/∂t and ∂E/∂t are partiel derivatives

She is considering (implicitly) a plane wave. This is one possible wave. It has infinite lateral extent, and this prevents it from spreading. To generate such a wave with any degree of accuracy, you need a source that is much wider than the wavelength. If the source is too small, the waves will diverge.  To get the right wave form corresponding to any given configuration of sources (moving charges), one needs to solve Maxwell's equations (with appropriate boundary conditions for the behavior 'far away'). All the phenomena of diffraction etc. can thus be described.  Maxwell's equations are linear. This means that one can take linear combinations of electromagnetic fields and these are again solutions to the equations. This provides ways to systematically construct solutions that are useful in further theoretical development and also in some practical situations. One approach is to synthesize solutions by adding plane waves. This is always possible, except at the very locations of the point charges (where the field is singular). So in this sense the plane wave is 'typical' and things we learn about it can be carried over to the more general case. BTW this synthesis of plane waves is called taking the 'Fourier transform' of the solution.  There are other ways to systematically synthesize solutions. One of particular theoretical importance is the so-called 'propagator' or 'Green's function' (there is some subtle nomenclature issue here, which I ignore). The idea is to solve the equations only once for a source consisting of a 'kick', i.e. a charge/current distribution that is located entirely in one point in space and one moment in time. Never mind the practicality of this for now: we just do the math. This yields a spherical wave that propagates outward from the source in a certain way (with a radial fall-off as you indicate). Now we synthesize any practical source configuration by taking a linear combination of 'kicks'. This is always possible. And we obtain the em-field for this extended source as a linear combination of 'kick solutions' or 'Green's functions'. This approach is of tremendous power and utility.

Thanks for the answer, but I couldn't really understand too well, mainly because I don't have the rhetoric to fully interpret your text (infinite lateral extent, linear combinations of electromag. fields, synthesize solutions, etc.).

Delivery too fast, distracting elements in animations, bad use of color, and didactic choices regarding mathematical formulation are conceivable reasons. They are inherent in the Crash Course format, but not everyone considers the format optimal for communicating this material.  I have not made up my mind about this course yet. I greatly appreciate presentation of this material for a wide audience, but each time I view an episode it feels 'forced' in a way that the other CC courses do not. Physics differs from many other subjects in its tight interconnections. These extend far beyond everyday experience and hence require care and deliberation before they can be accepted. Care and deliberation do not fit well with the upbeat CC presentation. The pace of Lenny Susskind's 'Theoretical Minimum' courses, for example, feels more suitable. Maybe the young generation is happier with the fast pace and the flashy decorations. (I'm an old man, and very well familiar with the material: so perhaps not the best judge.)

Rand Huso It's amazing that Maxwell proved the speed of light is constant and everyone believed his results, but nobody understood or believed the implications... until Einstein 20 years later.

+Sam Sorry, he didn't prove anything. The result that electromagnetic waves travel (in vacuum) at a constant velocity we now call c just popped out of the equations as a result. That's not a proof but a theoretical deduction, which turned out to be absolutely correct as it perfectly matched the observations. A theoretical deduction alone is NEVER a proof. It's just an indication, that needs to be verified by observation. That's important, because there is lot's of theoretical math out there, which leads to predictions, that are completely in contrast to reality/observation. Natural behavior can be astonishingly good described by mathematics, but just because I describe something mathematically, doesn't man nature has to follow this. Maths describes natural behavior, but nature doesn't follow maths. Don't get me wrong, I don't want to diminish Maxwell's task in any way (his equations are unquestionably one of the most brilliant and important physical works of all time), but theoretical deductions aren't worth the paper they are written on, if they are not validated by observation.

My argument was simply that some people do not have a scientific background and might therefore be unable to appreciate the video in its entirety because of it. When you do not understand something and there are no pauses it's easy to fall behind just like in a normal Course. Sure you can pause the video yourself but i'd argue that should not be nessecary.    However I do not know what philosophy the creators of this Channel have for their content. Is it their philosophy that you should pause, go back and repeat certain parts of the video for "The complete experience"?  If so then fine, i understand their choices of editing. If not then i'd say they're doing their viewers a slight disservice.( Note the SLIGHT part).  In the end education is not a black or white issue. Some people like this format and learn best from it and others do not. I am arguing that more would understand the discussed subject better If more pauses were added.   I am also not sure If I think it is crashcourse's job to make us "learn" this subject but to introduce us to it via easy to understand mathematical arguments and broad strokes. They have absolutely succeded in this when it Comes to the content of their videos but not always in the implementation and i think this series is an example of this. It's a great series but a bit fast-paced for many people.   Plz don't hate me crashcourse employees! I loves your videos but because this is a subject close to my heart i get a bit critical. It is a hard subject to teach and you're doing far better than most would!   Kisses and hugs!

Rarely is the YouTube comments section genuinely useful for epiphanies, but y'all's brief exchange just gave me an epiphany that led me to figure out, mathematically, how inductors store energy in their magnetic field, after I briefly revisited my notes for a DC Unit Circuit that I thought experimented: E=PT (Energy produced/used is equal to power generated/consumed over time) E=IVT (Substitute P=VI, Power is equal to voltage multiplied by current) E=Iφ (Substitute VT=φ, A change in voltage over time generates magnetic flux in a loop or coil) E=IIL (Substitute φ=IL, the magnetic flux in a loop or coil is equal to the inductance of the coil multiplied by the current through the coil) E=I²L (Simplify, the energy stored in an inductor is equal to its inductance multiplied by the current through it squared).  Thank you. <3 I have one more piece to use to improve my DC Unit Circuit.

a capacitor stores ENERGY as an electric field an inductor stores ENERGY as a magnetic field. there are no extra charges on a capacitor just a changing electric field similarly the increasing current through an inductor produces magnetic field lines...in both cases the "charges" are in motion doing their thing not getting stored themselves.

@calyodelphi124  you are almost right, but not quite. You dropped a 1/2 factor from your result. The mistake is in the E=IVT step. You suppose that I and V are constant here, but really, if V is constant I can not be. Not counting resistance, if V is constant I increases uniformly in an inductance. This results in P not being constant, and hence PT is not E. In that line you have to insert an 1/2 factor. To derive this properly, you have to use integrals, or reason based on graphing the power in time, and calculating the area under it. (Really, it's the same as integrating.)
